content:
In this tutorial we review earlier work that models grammatical structure. We introduce the notion of a context-free grammar and consider how to parse sentences using this grammar. We also introduce the CYK algorithm.

content:
Another model of appraisal and emotion, the OCC Model having several variables (including time, events, and the feeler's connection to the world).

In #NLProc, this model has been used before. In some papers they use a syntax parser to find time, event polarity dictionaries, etc.

content:
How are events related to emotions? Emotions themselves ARE events, but also emotions are CAUSED by events. 

#NLProc, needs to be able to INFER what kinds of situations cause fear (i.e. a burning car). "show, don't tell", e.g. classification without explicit "I'm angry" in text.
renderedContent:
How are events related to emotions? Emotions themselves ARE events, but also emotions are CAUSED by events. 

#NLProc, needs to be able to INFER what kinds of situations cause fear (i.e. a burning car). "show, don't tell", e.g. classification without explicit "I'm angry" in text.

content:
What do #NLProc researchers want to do in emotion analysis ?  Input text, and output categories such as "joy". 

Why do we want to do this? To find out how ppl represent text in language, i.e. analyze novels or songtexts. But also: knowledge of emotions and reactions to events.

content:
Another is Plutchik's wheel, with intensity as well. This is a discussed theory in psychology, but is often used in #NLProc. Also has relations between emotions.

Another model is valence-arousal model, modelling affect (not the same as emotions, more axeis of emotions).

So BERT thinks that the probability that Britney Spears is 100 yo > the probability she's 36 yo (her true age when BERT was released). 
This is also true for the year before (if pretraining occurred in a year prior to BERT's release).

content:
Just heard word2vec (2013) being described as an 'ancient method' by a computer scientist, compared to BERT. 😬 

Guess #NLProc is really a fast-moving field. 

(Might be surprising to other fields, where basic statistical models from the 20th century are still happily in use.)

content:
For those in #NLProc, what do you consider "data" to refer to in our field?

Utterances = speech signal/video for spoken/signed language, text for written

Labels = annotations of any type, naturally occurring, manually added, automatically added
